block.p: Divisions in Israel over the essence of the Jewish state are shown in the rapid growth of a religious movement, and it is clear that the Prime Minister's assassination grew out of these divisions. 1
In Israel, a suspect was said to be a security informer. 13
A Vatican statement added the word "infallible" to the ban on women as priests, seemingly strengthening it, but it also opened the way for new debate. 1
An emotional outburst at a funeral by Haiti's President has caused panic among the country's elite and undermined relations with other countries. 1
Peace talks were tense as the Bosnian Government asked the United States to provide support to insure military parity with the Bosnian Serbs, an issue considered a major stumbling block. 10
Within weeks after a Bosnia peace agreement, peacekeepers will start arriving, and more than any military operation since the Persian Gulf war, logistics will determine its initial success. 10
A Western look for Poland's former Communist candidate. 4
As Asian leaders gather in Osaka, protecting a city's image. 14
Remarks in Okinawa rekindled criticism about Navy insensitivity. 14
In Kashmir, a political and hostage standoff continues. 6
Despite signs that Congress and President Clinton were making progress on reopening Government offices, neither side reported getting any closer to an official agreement. 1
As President Clinton prepares to veto the budget-balancing bill, Administration officials are completing proposals to achieve a similar goal while protecting programs for poor and elderly people. 1
These are mean, scrappy days in the House -- in part because of the raw animosities that have flourished over the course of a bitter year, and in part because of cold-blooded political strategy. 20
Senator Bob Dole won the Florida Republican straw poll, but a close finish could be a sign of a hard-fought primary season ahead. 30
California might back away from rules requiring that 2 percent of the cars sold in the state be powered by electricity two years from now. 25
Officials who preside over the nation's foster care programs said that an already overburdened system would be flooded by refugees under the proposed restructuring of welfare. 1
In the eastern Mohave Desert, a group of environmental guerrillas wants to stop a low-level nuclear waste dump. 18
The nation's overall crime rate dropped 2 percent in 1994, the third consecutive year it has fallen, with a 4 percent decrease in the rate of violent crimes, a report says. 18
The crew members of the shuttle Atlantis and the Russian space station Mir returned to routine tasks after the spacecraft uncoupled. 19
At a conference, prosecutors, judges and police officers looked at police corruption in Philadelphia, New York and New Orleans. 33

By agreeing to unusually long labor contracts this month, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani did more than simply secure labor peace through the next century. He has now emphatically revealed how he will overhaul government, and how he will not. 1

Vilified from the outside as provocateurs of Yitzhak Rabin's assassination and roiled from within by self-examination, the Orthodox Jewish community has been profoundly shaken by the slaying and divided over how to respond. 41

Representatives Edolphus Towns and Charles B. Rangel, black politicians who represent largely black districts in New York City, might appear to be unlikely candidates to accept the tobacco industry's largesse. But they are among the House of Representatives' top 20 recipients of tobacco money. 41

In the 29 months since the Golden Venture ran aground off New York City with its cargo of illegal Asian immigrants, the operation's accused mastermind, who was arrested in Thailand on Friday, has apparently continued to enjoy the vast profits of the human smuggling trade, investigators said. 41
